articles.headline: F.B.I. Is Investigating Trump’s Russia Ties, Comey Confirms
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. chief’s remarks created a treacherous political moment for the president and placed a criminal investigation at the doorstep of the White House.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. chief’s remarks created a treacherous political moment for the president and placed a criminal investigation at the doorstep of the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, took the extraordinary step on Monday of announcing that the agency is investigating whether members of President Trump’s campaign colluded with Russia to influence the 2016 election.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Matthew Rosenberg and Emmarie Huetteman

articles.headline: After Dutch Election, Eurogroup Leader’s Fate Looks in Doubt
articles.snippet: Jeroen Dijsselbloem appears to be on the way out as head of the Eurogroup, the 19 finance ministers from countries that share the euro. He has presided over a tumultuous period.
articles.abstract: Jeroen Dijsselbloem appears to be on the way out as head of the Eurogroup, the 19 finance ministers from countries that share the euro. He has presided over a tumultuous period.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — They discussed Greece’s bailout. They grappled with pension issues. They pored over draft budgets.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Despite a Trust, Ivanka Trump Still Wields Power Over Her Brand
articles.snippet: Ms. Trump may address potential conflicts by recusing herself from related White House business or by vetoing a deal for her company, said an ethics lawyer who advises her.
articles.abstract: Ms. Trump may address potential conflicts by recusing herself from related White House business or by vetoing a deal for her company, said an ethics lawyer who advises her.
articles.lead_paragraph: What role Ivanka Trump plays in her father’s White House is among the pressing questions at the intersection of politics and business under the Trump administration.

articles.headline: Opposition and a Shave: Former Obama Aides Counter Trump
articles.snippet: Former members of the Obama White House are using their podcast, “Pod Save America,’’ to counter President Trump on his terrain. (And they have advertisers.)
articles.abstract: Former members of the Obama White House are using their podcast, “Pod Save America,’’ to counter President Trump on his terrain. (And they have advertisers.)
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The cultural-political revolution of the Nixon era was neither televised nor sponsored. If you listen to the coolest protest anthem ever, “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised,” by Gil Scott-Heron, you’ll hear that it was not “brought to you by Xerox,” did not “go better with Coke,” did not have stars like Natalie Wood and Steve McQueen or the entertainment value of “Green Acres.”

articles.headline: What Investigation? G.O.P. Responds to F.B.I. Inquiry by Changing Subject
articles.snippet: As the F.B.I. director acknowledged an investigation into ties between presidential associates and Russia, Republicans instead focused on leaks to news organizations.
articles.abstract: As the F.B.I. director acknowledged an investigation into ties between presidential associates and Russia, Republicans instead focused on leaks to news organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The headline from Capitol Hill on Monday was bracing: confirmation of a criminal investigation into connections between associates of a sitting president and Russian operatives during a presidential election.

articles.headline: House Republicans Turn to Upstate New York to Lure Votes for Health Bill
articles.snippet: A provision that would shift Medicaid costs from New York’s counties to the state was added to the health care bill, a move sought by upstate Republicans.
articles.abstract: A provision that would shift Medicaid costs from New York’s counties to the state was added to the health care bill, a move sought by upstate Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders, trying to lock down the votes of wavering upstate New York Republicans, inserted a last-minute special provision in their health care bill that would shift Medicaid costs from New York’s counties to its state government.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: School Choice Fight in Iowa May Preview the One Facing Trump
articles.snippet: Iowa is one of 31 states where legislators have proposed creating or expanding school choice programs this year, but the push is meeting resistance.
articles.abstract: Iowa is one of 31 states where legislators have proposed creating or expanding school choice programs this year, but the push is meeting resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — When she was shopping for a school for her daughter Alma, Mary Kakayo found a lot to like in St. Theresa Catholic, including its Catholic social justice theme, student prayer and hour of religious instruction every day.

articles.headline: Becoming Duterte: The Making of a Philippine Strongman
articles.snippet: He is a child of privilege turned populist politician, an antidrug crusader who has struggled with drug abuse. Obsessed with death, he has turned his violent vision into national policy.
articles.abstract: He is a child of privilege turned populist politician, an antidrug crusader who has struggled with drug abuse. Obsessed with death, he has turned his violent vision into national policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVAO CITY, Philippines — President Rodrigo Duterte relishes the image of killer-savior. He boasts of killing criminals with his own hand. On occasion, he calls for mass murder.

articles.headline: Devices Banned on Flights From 10 Countries Over ISIS Fears
articles.snippet: The United States and Britain have restricted electronic devices larger than a cellphone being carried on some flights from majority-Muslim countries.
articles.abstract: The United States and Britain have restricted electronic devices larger than a cellphone being carried on some flights from majority-Muslim countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence showing that the Islamic State is developing a bomb hidden in portable electronics spurred the United States and Britain on Tuesday to bar passengers from airports in a total of 10 Muslim-majority countries from carrying laptop computers, iPads and other devices larger than a cellphone aboard direct inbound flights, two senior American counterterrorism officials said.
articles.byline: By Ron Nixon, Adam Goldman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: What’s at Stake in a Health Bill That Slashes the Safety Net
articles.snippet: By reversing the Medicaid expansion and leaving millions unable to pay for coverage, the bill would be a landmark retreat in American social welfare.
articles.abstract: By reversing the Medicaid expansion and leaving millions unable to pay for coverage, the bill would be a landmark retreat in American social welfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do we lose when social insurance unravels?

articles.headline: Trump Warns House Republicans: Repeal Health Law or Lose Your Seats
articles.snippet: The president threatened wavering lawmakers with political payback as Republican officials conceded that they still lacked the votes to pass their bill.
articles.abstract: The president threatened wavering lawmakers with political payback as Republican officials conceded that they still lacked the votes to pass their bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday turned up the pressure on recalcitrant Republicans to support a sweeping bill to overhaul the health care system, threatening wavering lawmakers in his party with political payback if they failed to get behind a measure that has become an early test of his negotiating power.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear
